questions.text: What is the ultimate desired state towards which objectives and resources are aimed in the medical field?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer - Option C: Goal

Explanation:

Goal in health planning represents the ultimate desired state that directs all objectives and resources.

  • Not constrained by time and resources
  • Timeframe guideline - should not extend beyond a five-year period.

Incorrect Options:

Target (Option A): It measures the degree of achievement of objectives.

  • E.g. To complete the objective, i.e., increase immunization coverage by 60%., one needs to target conducting 1 health education session per week.

Mission (Option B): It refers to the overall purpose or reason for the existence of an organization or entity.

Plan (Option D): It refers to a detailed course of action outlining how specific objectives will be achieved.

questions.text: An urban city has a population of 70,00,000, with 30% residing in slum areas. According to NUHM (National Urban Health Mission) norms, how many Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHCs) are required for the slum population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – 42:

Explanation:

  • Under NUHM guidelines, one Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) is established for every 50,000 people living in slums.
    • Total population = 7,000,000
    • Slum population = 30% of 7,000,000 = 2,100,000
    • Required UPHCs = 2,100,000 ÷ 50,000 = 42
    • This ensures equitable access to primary healthcare services for underserved urban slum populations.

questions.text: A group of experts delivered individual speeches on a common topic. There was no discussion allowed between them, and at the end, one person summarized the key points. What is this type of academic session called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Symposium

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is Symposium because it involves experts giving individual speeches on a single topic without interaction between them. At the end, a chairperson or moderator summarizes the content presented.

Panel discussion (Option A): Experts discuss a topic among themselves and respond to audience questions.

Seminar (Option C): In-depth study session, often interactive, on a specific topic for a small audience.

Workshop (Option D): Hands-on, practical training session with active participation.

questions.text: The most accurate representation of maternal mortality ratio (MMR) for a nation is
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.

The maternal mortality ratio (MMR) is a key indicator used to measure maternal health and assess the risk of maternal death during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days after the end of pregnancy. It is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. (Maternal deaths per 100 live births) is not as accurate because it does not account for the larger scale of live births, which makes it difficult to compare MMR between different populations.

Option B. (Maternal deaths per 10,000 live births) is also not the best choice because it overestimates the MMR by using a smaller denominator (10,000) compared to option C.

Option D. (Maternal deaths per 1,000 live births) is not appropriate either because it underestimates the MMR by using a larger denominator (1,000) compared to option C.

Therefore, option C, which represents the MMR as maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, provides the most accurate and widely used representation of this indicator.

questions.text: Under which benefit in the ESI act do beneficiaries receive 70% of their wages for a duration of 3 months?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Sickness benefit

Explanation:In the ESI act, the beneficiaries are offered 70% wages for 91 days continuously. An extended sickness benefit is provided for 34 diseases including TB, leprosy, HIV, and mental illness for 2 years at 80% of daily wages.

Benefits of ESI (Employees State Insurance) Act

Medical Benefit (Option B ruled out)
  • Provides "full medical care," including hospitalization at no cost to insured individuals & families in cases of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

Sickness Benefit (Option A)
  • Provides 70% of average daily wages in cash during medical leave for a maximum of 91 days within 365 days, as certified by the Insurance Medical Officer/Practitioner.

Extended Sickness Benefit
  • Extended coverage for long-term diseases beyond 91 days; 34 diseases covered if employed for two years.
  • Extended sickness benefit is paid at 80% of the insured person's wages.

Enhanced Sickness Benefit
  • Cash benefits (100% wages) for sterilization procedures:
    • 14 days for tubectomy (women),
    • 7 days for vasectomy (men).

Maternity Benefit (Option C ruled out)

 
  • Cash payments for childbirth, miscarriage, or pregnancy-related sickness:
    • 26 weeks for childbirth,
    • 6 weeks for miscarriage, and
    • 40 days for pregnancy-related sickness.
  • Paid at 100% of the insured woman's average daily wages.

Disablement Benefit

 
  • Temporary Disablement Benefit (TDB):
    • 90% of wages paid from day one for temporary employment injury, until recovery.
  • Permanent Disablement Benefit (PDB):
    • 90% of wages paid monthly for life, based on certified loss of earning capacity.

Dependent's Benefit (Option D ruled out)
  • Dependents receive 90% of the deceased's (due to employment injuries) wages as a shared pension, and they are eligible until age 18.
  • If the daughter marries before 18, the benefit is withdrawn.

Funeral Expenses
  • It offers a cash payment of up to Rs. 15,000 to cover funeral expenses upon the death of an insured individual.

Rehabilitation

 
  • Insured individuals and their families are entitled to continued medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.
  • They have to pay a nominal fee of Rs.10 per month for this benefit.
  • A rehabilitation allowance of Rs.15,000 granted.

Unemployment allowance
  • For eligible employees due to factory closure or retrenchment: 50% of wage for up to two years.

choices.text: National institute of health & family welfare (NIHFW)

questions.solution:
Correct Option C) National planning commission (NPC)

Explanation:

The full form of NITI Aayog is National Institution for Transforming India. It replaced the planning commission on January 1, 2015.

  • NITI Aayog is the organization responsible for developing the Health Index in India. The Health Index is a composite measure that tracks the performance of Indian states and Union Territories on various health indicators. Eg. Neonatal Mortality Rate, Under-5 Mortality Rate, etc.
  • NITI Aayog replaced Planning Commission of India in 2015, acts as a think tank to the central and state governments on policy matters, including health.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare collaborates with NITI Aayog and provides data but is not the primary organization for evaluating and releasing the Health Index.
  • The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) focuses on biomedical research and is not involved in creating the Health Index. The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international body that provides health-related guidelines and support but does not develop the Health Index for India.

 

Medical Council of India (MCI) (Option A): The MCI was a statutory body that regulates medical education. The MCI has been replaced by by the National Medical Commission (NMC) to enhance transparency and improve medical education standards.

National Institute of Health & Family Welfare (NIHFW) (Option B): The NIHFW is an autonomous organization under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in India, the NIHFW has not been replaced by NITI Aayog.

National Board of Examinations (NBE) (Option D): The NBE is an autonomous body responsible for conducting postgraduate medical examinations in India. The NBE has not been replaced by NITI Aayog.

questions.text: Which of the following is defined as the systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D- Work sampling

Explanation:

  • Work sampling refers to the systematic observation and recording of activities performed by one or more individuals at predetermined or random intervals. It is a technique used in industrial engineering and management to gather data about how work is being conducted, how time is allocated, and how resources are utilized.

Work Sampling does not involve calculating project costs or evaluating monetary benefits.

  • It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks, aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement.

  • It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities.

  • It is a type of quantitative health management technique.

Model (Option A): It refers to a conceptual or mathematical representation used to simulate, predict, or explain real-world phenomena. This option is incorrect.

Decision making (Option B): It is a cognitive process involving the selection of a course of action from available alternatives. This option is incorrect.

Personnel management (Option C): It involves the administration of human resources within an organization, including recruitment, training, performance evaluation, and employee relations. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Newborn

  • Navjaat Sishu Suraksha Karyakaram is a 2-day training provided to healthcare workers/medical officers in newborn care and resuscitation.

Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK)
  • A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia.
  • The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity.

Goals/Objectives
  • Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030.
  • Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care.
  • Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia.

Strategies

  • Capacity Building: Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills.
  • Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training.
  • Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology
  • Standardized Equipment and Supplies: Provide clean, functional equipment.
  • Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer: Improve practical application of training.
  • Focus on "Golden Minute": Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies.
  • Timely Immunization: Ensure vaccination before discharge.
  • Educate parents on newborn care.
  • Effective Neonatal Transport: Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is the financial advantage quantified?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cost-benefit Analysis

  • Cost-benefit analysis: Cost-benefit analysis measures the outcome of a program in monetary terms. It compares the economic benefits and cost of the program.

Incorrect Options:

Cost-effective analysis (Option A): Cost-effective analysis measures outcome of a program in nonmonetary terms .

Network analysis (Option C): A graphic plan of all events to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Input-output analysis (Option D): It is an economic technique. Monetary benefits are not measured in this technique.

questions.text: Which of the following methods relies on the principles of behavioral sciences?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Management by objective

Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences.

  • Qualitative type of health management is based on behavioral sciences. It includes
    • Personal management
    • Organizational design
    • Communication
    • Information system
    • Management by objective

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & C are incorrect.

  • Decision making, network analysis, and system analysis is Quantitative which is not based on behavioral sciences.

questions.text: Which of the following is assessed by evaluating the patient's treatment and clinical management in a healthcare facility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Process

Explanation:

  • The Process of healthcare evaluation refers to the methods and actions taken during patient care. This includes the assessment of how the patient is managed, the treatments administered, and the clinical decisions made by healthcare providers during their treatment in a healthcare facility.

Components of healthcare evaluation:

Evaluation Type

Description

Focus

Purpose

Structure Evaluation (Option C ruled out)

Assesses the resources and organizational components of healthcare facilities.

Infrastructure, staff qualifications, medical equipment

Ensure the healthcare facility has adequate resources, equipment, and trained staff.

Process Evaluation

Assesses how healthcare services are delivered, focusing on procedures and practices.

Clinical guidelines, care delivery methods, patient interactions

Ensure care is aligned with best practices and protocols.

Outcome Evaluation (Option A ruled out)

Evaluates the results of healthcare interventions.

Health outcomes, symptom improvement, recovery, patient satisfaction

Determine the effectiveness of treatments and interventions in improving health.

Input Evaluation (Option D ruled out)

Assesses the resources available for healthcare.

Financial resources, staff levels, medical supplies

Ensure sufficient resources for effective healthcare delivery.

Cost-Effectiveness Evaluation

Assesses whether the intervention provides good value for the cost.

Cost relative to health outcomes, alternative treatments

Ensure the efficient use of resources and value for money in healthcare.

Patient-Centered Evaluation

Focuses on patient experience and satisfaction.

Patient satisfaction, provider-patient relationship, treatment understanding

Ensure care aligns with patient needs and improves their experience and compliance.

 

Components of health program evaluation:

Component

Definition

Key Focus Areas

Relevance

Assesses whether the program addresses the priority health needs of the target population.

Disease burden, target group needs, alignment with public health goals.

Adequacy

Evaluates whether the resources and scale of the program are sufficient to achieve the intended outcomes.

Coverage, resource allocation, unmet needs.

Accessibility

Measures how easily beneficiaries can access program services.

Geographic, financial, and cultural barriers to access.

Acceptability

Determines whether the program is acceptable to beneficiaries and stakeholders.

Community participation, cultural compatibility, stakeholder feedback.

Equity

Assesses whether the program reduces disparities in health outcomes and services.

Reach among marginalized populations, fairness in resource distribution.

Efficiency

Evaluates the optimal use of resources to achieve desired outcomes.

Cost-efficiency, time management, operational performance.

Effectiveness

Measures the extent to which the program achieves its objectives and desired outcomes.

Reduction in morbidity and mortality, behavior changes, program goals met.

questions.text: In a hospital setting, the management seeks to determine the average duration of doctor-patient interactions in order to assess the need for adjusting the number of doctors. This adjustment is aimed at enhancing the quality of care provided. Which management technique would be most appropriate for this purpose?

questions.text: A doctor is consulted by a woman who is 8 weeks pregnant and employed in an industry. As per the ESI act, what is the length of maternity leave she is entitled to?

choices.text: 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery
26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

Explanation:

  • As per the ESI Act and Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017, eligible women are entitled to 26 weeks of paid maternity leave, starting from 8 weeks before the expected delivery date for their first two children.

 

4 months (Option A): is incorrect because the ESI Act provides maternity leave benefits up to 26 weeks, not 4 months, and the 28-week clause is not applicable.

28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery (Option C): is incorrect because maternity leave typically starts before delivery, not just after delivery, and the duration stated exceeds the legal limit.

9 months (Option D): is incorrect because the ESI Act does not grant maternity leave for such a long duration.

questions.text: According to WHO, what proportions of GNP should be spent on health services?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 5%

Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that 5% of a country's Gross National Product (GNP) should be spent on health services.
  • This target is suggested to ensure that countries can provide adequate healthcare services, improve public health infrastructure, and address healthcare needs of the population.

 

2% (Option A): is incorrect because the WHO's recommendation is higher than 2%. The figure of 2% is often lower than the minimum threshold suggested by the WHO.

2.5% (Option B): is incorrect because the WHO recommends 5% and not 2.5% for a more optimal investment in the health sector.

3.5% (Option C): is incorrect because, although it’s a reasonable figure for some countries, the WHO’s recommendation is 5%, which is slightly higher.

questions.text: Hyperpigmentation and keratosis can be seen with which of the following:

questions.text: What is the denominator used in the calculation of case fatality rate?

choices.text: Total number of deaths due to all causes
Total number of cases due to the disease concerned
Total number of deaths due to the disease concerned

questions.solution:
Correct Option. C

  • Total number of cases due to the disease concerned: This option represents the correct denominator for calculating the case fatality rate. The case fatality rate is calculated by dividing the number of deaths due to the disease concerned by the total number of cases related to that specific disease. It provides a measure of the proportion of individuals diagnosed with the disease who die from it.

Incorrect options 

Option A, B & D are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following recommendations was NOT made by the Chadha committee?

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: One PHC for 50,000 population

  •  The Chadha Committee, which was primarily focused on the National Malaria Eradication Programme, did not specifically recommend one PHC for every 50,000 population. Instead, its recommendations were more focused on integrating malaria eradication activities into general health services, particularly at the PHC level. The exact recommended ratio of PHCs to population was not mentioned in the committee's report.

Incorrect Options

Option A: PHC at block level

  • The Chadha Committee did recommend the establishment of PHCs at the block level. This recommendation was aimed at decentralizing healthcare and improving access to primary health services across different regions.

Option C: One basic health worker per 10,000 population

  • The Chadha Committee suggested having one basic health worker per 10,000 population to ensure that there were enough healthcare providers available at the grassroots level to carry out primary healthcare services effectively.

Option D: Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

  • The Chadha Committee emphasized the role of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme, assigning them responsibilities in the detection, treatment, and prevention of malaria. This integration was part of the broader strategy to utilize existing healthcare infrastructure for disease control programs.
